<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 868, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a metre ruler using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[106, 128, 892, 237]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 255, 532, 274]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 285, 146, 304]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 285, 175, 304]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 285, 475, 304]]<|/det|> Place the metre ruler on the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 301, 176, 319]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 301, 771, 319]]<|/det|> Place the load P on the metre ruler with its centre at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 316, 176, 335]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 316, 920, 350]]<|/det|> Keeping P at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark, adjust the position of the metre ruler on the pivot so that the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 363, 920, 397]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the distance \(a\) from the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 920, 458]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the distance \(b\) from the pivot to the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) end of the metre ruler. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 486, 920, 520]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps above, placing the load P at the \(85.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(80.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(75.0 \text{cm}\) mark and \(70.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Record the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 533, 541, 551]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 560, 641, 727]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 722, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 483, 920, 520]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 530, 920, 572]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the resistance \(R\) of \(20.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire. Use the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 580, 667, 599]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 851, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the magnification of the image produced by a lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 680, 120]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 880, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 300, 534, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 326, 698, 481]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 495, 591, 514]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 543, 146, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 543, 920, 577]]<|/det|>
Measure the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the illuminated object provided. Fig. 3.2 shows the height to be measured on your object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 573, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h_{\mathrm{O}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[918, 574, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 604, 146, 622]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 604, 730, 622]]<|/det|>
Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 833, 638]]<|/det|>
Move the screen slowly until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 774, 653]]<|/det|>
Measure the distance \(\nu\) between the centre of the lens and the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 651, 376, 668]]<|/det|>
Record \(\nu\) in Table 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 666, 873, 685]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the magnification \(m\) using the equation \(m = \frac{\nu}{U}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 685, 873, 700]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the height of the image \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 701, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the ratio \(\frac{h_{I}}{h_{\mathrm{O}}}\) , where \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) is the height of the object recorded in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 737, 531, 755]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure using \(u = 30.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 912, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the time taken for water to evaporate to dryness when heated from above.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 633, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up. The power of the heater is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 371, 151]]<|/det|>
The following is also available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 138, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 457, 183]]<|/det|>
supply of water at room temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 181, 253, 198]]<|/det|>
• metre ruler.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 203, 828, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 355, 532, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 387, 917, 405]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how one factor affects the time taken for the water to evaporate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 418, 487, 437]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 450, 536, 467]]<|/det|>
You do **not** need to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 481, 218, 497]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 512, 480, 529]]<|/det|>
• state any additional apparatus required

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 528, 566, 545]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how you would do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 543, 591, 560]]<|/det|>
• state the key variables that you would keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 559, 918, 592]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 590, 683, 607]]<|/det|>
• explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.
